ZOLTAN IS THE BEST!!. We toured with Zoltan for two days. He is charismatic, brilliant, zany, and just the best. Whaterever you want, he can provide it. Be sure to go out to dinner with him--not your usual tourist traps. We had a great two days and quite an eclectic experience. Would use him again.

Zoltan Nagy - The Hungarian Indiana Jones?. Spend some time with Zoltan. It's worth every penny. Ask him about himself - if you've got a spare day! We did the Danube bend. Just the two of us so not cheap but what an informative day and what pleasant company to be in. Is there anything he doesn't know or have an opinion on? I don't know. He certainly doesn't know those words.even though his English is impeccable - for a Magyar. If you don't want to pay the full eight person rate for a smaller party then call him yourself and see if there's a tour to share. Get his contact details at www.rockhoppers.hu.

Zoltan in the best. Zoltan NAGY is a great guide for Budapest. He is a professor of Inner Asian Studies and is fluent in six languages including English. We toured with him for two full days plus airport transfers and private dinners. He is extremely knowledgible and social. He will gear the touring to your wishes and show you parts of Budapest that tourists do not always see. There were only four of us and he became our friend and drinking buddy. Not your stuffy tour experience! He brought us back to the sixties with his ponytail, beard, and sandals...looks like Sean Connery with a beard. Well worth the money.

Fabulous tailor made tour. Zoltan incorporated all we aked for and more in our tailor made tour of BudapestWe were only in Budapest for a couple of days, so wanted to see a lot of the city quickly, and Zoltan deliveredWe saw parts of the city we didn't even know to ask for - City Park, coffee houses, Jewish prayer house, spas - not to mention St Stephen's Basilica - where we wouldn't have known to look for St Stephen's hand if we hadn't had Zoltan.Zoltan was knowledgeable, funny and enthusiastic - he gave us more tour than we had asked for - definitely best tour we've had

Great day!. We toured the Jewish Quarter with Zoltan Nagy on Sept. 18th. We saw many interesting sites and learned so much. We asked for directions to see the shoes on the Danube and he took us there also. Zoltan is highly recommended.. a highlight of our Budapest visit!

Rockhoppers; the only way to see Budapest!!!. Ask for Zoltan; no other tour guide in Budapest will do. We had the pleasure of spending all day with Zoltan, exploring the Danube Bend and the towns outside Budapest. His insight and knowledge, together with his vibrant personalty, opened our eyes to the true Hungary. As we explored the ruins of Visegrad Castle, the small village of Szentendre or the famed Basicllica at Esztergom, Zoltan shared stories and observations which made these sights come alive. Had we met sooner, we surely would have used Zoltan and Rockhoppers for other tours throughout Budapest. Having utilized many tour guides throughout Europe, we would give Zoltan our highest recommendation. He is a true diamond in the rough.

Budapest, from a different perspective. In the last two years, I've been to this city about a dozen times or more. I'm comfortable with it and I know it quite well - or so I thought.I found the Rockhoppers tour through a brochure at a hostel and decided to try it out. I'm quite interested in different cultures that walk among us so the tour of the city's Jewish quarter seemed like a no-brainer.In all honesty, I was expecting to go to synagogues and hear the guide (Zoltan was his name) tell us about architecture and a few snippets of the culture, things that I'm already quite familiar with.I was wrong. Zoltan did an amazing job telling the group not just of the architectural periods but also the way the members of the Jewish quarter lived, how they managed to get on with other natives of Budapest, how they went through the second world war, etc. Not only that, but he had an interesting sense of humour so the tour was not at all dry.Overall, it was a fascinating tour and something off the beaten path, yet on the beaten path at the same time! Well worth the time. I definitely checking out the Rockhoppers tours.

Private guiding for free. We got toknow that there i s a walking tour in Budapest Jewish quartier through firends.It happened that only our small family of three was the group. Our guide Zoltan was extremely dedicated and he tailor-cut the tour after we told him what are we interested in. The highlight of our trip!. What can I say, Zoltan IS the Hungarian Indiana Jones! If you want special you MUST have Zoltan show you Budapest. migratory history book. a very personal walk through the old jewish quarter of budapest;

Tours of Budapest. The City Tour with Zoltan was the best that we have ever had in Europe. He is so knowledgeable and he took us to sites that you would not normally get on a regular city tour. If you want to see "real" historic sites and hear the story behind the history, then Zoltan is the one you choose We would highly recommend him. He is not only knowledgeable, but injects his sense of humour into the tours as well.

He Did Show Us New Things. I bumped by chance into Zoli in Budapest near the Opera and I estime myself lucky. He showed me parts of Budapest and the surroundings worth seeing but out of the usual paths. When we went to see a Gypsy community, I could make the difference between myths and reality. Moreover, he obviously has the talent to tailer the tour to the needs of the visitors and to the weather. Try Zoli.

Two great tours, one great Guide.. Soltan Nagy picked me up and deposited me safely back to my Hotel on the two tours I booked. He showed me a comprehensive tour of the Castle district with all the request I made of him. It was in depth and interesting as well as enlightening. His manner is cordial and his English outstanding.The second day we went on the tour of the Jewish quarter where several personal encounters with Rabies and students on the properties made my visits to Budapest one of the best ever. I would recommend his service to all who have the good fortune to book this guide. Iris Seefeldt

A tour with Zoltan is priceless. We spent an afternoon with Zoltan touring the Roman ruins in Budapest, then followed it up with a drive to the country for a wine tasting. The ruins were beautiful and educational, and the evening was excellent. The wine was great, the conversation was wonderful, and we had an unforgettable time. Be prepared to walk a bit outside for the Ruins tour; there are are four or five stops with the last one being a museum to the Roman town that used to occupy the site. After being outside with ruins, you will be wisked out of town to a small village, down skinny roads and a dirt road to an unassuming house above a beautiful grape orchard. There, you will be fed cheese, bread, and vegetables, introduced to the winemaker, and then wisked into the wine cellar. There, you will taste whites and reds from the region that will never see the inside of a commercial wine bottle. The wine tasted great, the experience was absolutely one of a kind, and I'll never forget the sunset over the vineyard. If your expecting a California-style wine tasting, with folks swishing wine around and spitting it out, you've come to the wrong place. Be prepared to leave really happy. Don't miss it.

We had a wonderful time with Zoltan!. My two friends and I had a wonderful day with Zoltan on the Danube Bend Tour. Zoltan was incredibly knowledgeable, amazingly generous with his time and completely flexible in respect to the various wishes of his guests. We had some great meals at out-of the-way places we never would have found on our own, saw some fascinating old towns and so much more. An exhausting day, but our best day in Hungary!

Roman Empire Tour with Zoltan. Four of us were fortunate enough to book a Roman tour of Budapest with Zoltan. The tour was very educational and we had an excellent time. The locations are available to find on your own, but would be difficult to get to/through in a reasonable time frame without a guide. Zoltan really knows his stuff and provides a much richer experience than just simply walking through locations and reading informational boards. The tour culminated with a visit to a local, organic vineyard in a small village. The views, wine, and company... all extraordinary and unique. When I visit wonderful places like Budapest I am often resistant to tours as I want to just explore on my own as there is so much to see I don't want to dive too deep into any one thing. I am very happy I didn't follow my normal trend this time. Thanks again Zoltan.

If you need a real guide, here he is!. I participated at a Jewish Tour and I enjoyed it very much. The guide,Zoltan, showed us parts of Budapest I never would have found on my own,e.g. a picturesque little prayer house hidden in some courtyard. Don'tmiss Zoltan, he is an expert. I have seen other tours elsewhere, but hereally made a difference by his knowledge and commitment.

What an amazing experience!. My husband and I took the Danube Bend Tour with Zoltan. We had the most amazing day. We enjoyed getting out of the city and seeing things we would have never seen otherwise. We crossed over into Slovakia to buy some cheese to have as a snack later and it was delicious. We got to see several amazing pieces of history on our way to and from the Forest Ranger's house. I especially loved the monastery and the site of the holy water. We got to eat real Hungarian food and were able to taste many different palinka's. We would definitely recommend taking any tour with Zoltan.

Exceptional ,free walking tour of Jewish area. This was a real treat....I have always said the best things in life are free,a free tour of the areas that hold so many poignant memories and secrets.I was so pleased that Zoltan offered to take me even though no-one else turned up..I have been to Budapest lots of timesbefore and wanted something different to do andto be able to listen to Zoltan imparting his great knowledge and stories about the area was an amazing experience.and better than reading any guidebook,infact perhaps it would help if guides eg Lonely planet,Rough guide and Time out wrote about Zoltans tours?.Hence I am posting this in an effort to spread the word about these tours i did feel sorry that I could not 'tip'more (I have recently become redundant and so money is tight!)

really made the trip what it was: amazing. the first time i met zoltan i thought he was someone my grandmother already knew and it turns out he was a complete stranger, so great was the connection.we were very lucky has a group to have found him.im a quarter hungarian which may seem like a small amount to most but i came away from the week in budapest feeling quite proud of that quarter and more connected to the country that i would have had we not gone on these tours.we ended up spending twice as long on the tours as supposed to and didnt even notice because he is so full of information and enthusiasm. I really couldnt have asked for a better experience.Do yourself a favor and book this, it will make hungary that much more alive.

Enjoyable afternoon in Jewish Quarter. Enjoyed our time with Zoltan. He showed us many interesting things in the Jewish Quarter which we would not have known walking on our own. He was familiar with the area history and architecture. I wish he had been able to describe more of the Jewish faith and what some of their symbols represent-esp as this was specifically a Jewish Quarter tour. It was a disappointment that we didn't get to see the big synagogue or the shoe Memorial. The tour was a little slow paced and if I were to make a recommendation, I would encourage you to be very clear up front about what you want to see and will things be open. It was a disappointment that he left the big synagogue til last and it was closed. Other than that, it was a good tour.

Fantastic Tours of Humanity. There are tours and there are tours. With Zoltan, every step you take you walk deeper into the heart and soul of not only Budapest, but Hungary. We went on the Gypsy tour and guided by his expertise, entered a universe that is not readily understandable to the lay person. We wined and dined and danced our hearts full connecting a bit to the gypsy in us all. We went on the Jewish tour, and every cobblestone we stepped on took us deeper into Budapest's Jewish community...buildings and streets and shamashes in each synogogue...replete with history of the past and present. We went on a Danube Bend tour, starting with Memento Park to the south, the Citadel with Natasha standing tall as the statue of Liberty forever to be behold, and onwards to the startling beauty of Szentendre...a living picturesque monument of past communities with people carrying on with their lives today and the smallest synogogue ever...to Esztergom...the road approaching the city with the most monumental basilica to St Stephan ever...enough to convert even the most suspect of fellows with its size, grandeur, marble, and gold...we went across the bridge to Slovakia to dance to Klezmer music on the banks of the Slovakian Danube...Zoltan's curiosity and erudition to cultural humanity, his sensitivity to his guests make his tours an unforgettable experience. What can I say? Without Zoltan, our trip would have been a collection of monuments, buildings and dates. Zoltan is forever at our dinner table and I don't have enough words to express my thanks and appreciation of his talents.

3 Tours with Zoltan. Surfing the internet I found Zoltan at Rockhoppers. We were planning a trip to Budapest.There were estatic reviews of the Rockhopper tours which convinced me to contact Zoltan.He picked us up at our hotel and drove us to a gypsy village. He introduced us to another world. Men and women dancing and drinking!! We,too,had drinks and goulash and danced. Our cameras didn't stop clicking.The next day Zoltan gave us the Jewish tour. We walked on cobblestones,went into old synagogues and were introduced to the Jewish communities which had made many contributions to the Hungarian society.The irony of it all. The Nazis herded 600,000 Jews and deported them to Auschwitz. Zoltan,an extremely educated and talented man,offered his observations of political and cultural events of Hungary. He opened up our minds and eyes.The 3rd tour, Zoltan took us to Castle Hill in Buda. it was twilight. We looked at the Danube and saw the lights of Pest and thought how lucky we were to have met ZoltanAnother peak into the Turkish community.Another wonderful tour day we went to Szentendre and Estergom and Slovakia!!!! We danced on the beach.Reluctantly we said goodbye and thanked Zoltan for being in our lives.Thalia

A great way to see and understand Budapest. We loved our walking tour through the Jewish district in Budapest. Zoltån Nagy was very knowledgeable and was able to adapt the tour to our needs ( mostly children) he was very personable to the kids which I found refreshing. We were able to go at our own pace and really enjoy the day. Only thing I would change is to have started earlier in the day, as we ran out of time.

An amazing insight into the less-seen city. I am incredibly grateful to have found Zoltan- he has taken us on tours of the Castle District and the 8th District, both extremely interesting parts of the city, made more interesting by Zoltan's knowledge and clear enthusiasm. His personal contacts in the 8th district added depth to the 8th district tour in particular, and our visit to the inside of the synagogue on Teleki square was an excellent addition. I fully recommend Rockhoppers to anyone interested in seeing the Budapest that is not necessarily on the surface!

Looking for a cultural adventure in downtown Budapest? Definitely go for this guided tour in the old Jewish Quarter!. Did you know that Jews settled down at the area, which is called today Budapest back in the 2nd and 3rd centuries? And their presence has been permanent at the area!Later they settled in the newly founded Buda town in the 13th century, as well, then in the Old Buda town, and finally in Pest. When they were already present all around, the three cities were united!They created a vivid life that started with a traditional religious way of life, and continued it all the way to the several Nobel Prizes for people born in Hungary.The Jewish Quarter is a great area now! Small and cozy restaurants, bars, cafés emanate the atmosphere of the old and the new life. Taste a kosher pastry called Flodni that contains poppy seeds, apples and walnuts! Try to get into Kazinczy Street 49, where there is an old fig tree in the yard. Take a look at a small, Sephardic synagogue in an apartment situated at the most dangerous district of the town. Try Bar Ladino! (Enlisted on Tripadvisor, too.) Jump in the Yeshiva of the Chabad Lubavich during a class, when bohers study with their rabbis and where pigeons fly into the class sometimes! Ask your guide to drive you in a cemetery where there are beautiful Art Nouveau crypts! Have a lunch at a kosher restaurant, where it is the steam of the kitchen that welcomes you still before you meet the waiter! Take a chance with the market of the district, built by the office of Eiffel, where the Roma sell their vegetables outside, and you can taste the fried meat inside that the locals eat!These guys organized it for us. Aren’t you curious?

A real hit. We found Rockhoppers on Tripadvisor, and it was a real hit! The Jewish Tour was a deep-diving into the pre-Holocaust Jewish life of Budapest.Talking to people in the synagogues, on the streets proved for us that the area is still a living region! It was worth traveling that far!

Great tour & wines!. When you get tired – though you are taken by a car all way long – watching the amazing Roman buildings and ruins in Budapest, the second half of the tour will be a salvation!THE TOP!A wine cellar with several great wines and snacks as home made sausages, cheese … and a charming old man, the owner ...It is a great composition of visual and other kinds of enjoyment!

Really brilliant - this is what you will not see with a regular guide. These tours are really engaging and exciting tour, and I recommend it to anybody who would like to see a little more than what is normally offered and described in tour guides and in the National Geographic style type of accounts of Hungary. No rosy stories, but rather the grit and grime of contemporary Eastern Europe. Especially the Roma parts are interesting and worthwhile - not because they are romantic (playful gypsies with flowers in their hair) but rather the real image of realities of life. On top of that, there is Zoltan, who's really fun and a great person, well informed and with access to places/people that no outsider would have, and who drives you around in really unexpected places... :) And he is also very hospitable - in the truly East European style - you know what I mean :)))

Rockhoppers = Great Hungarian Hospitality. Wow! My intrepid journey was absolutely amazing and very special with "rockhoppers"! Many thanks for Zoltan who prepared for us a fantastic tour around Budapest and suburbs. That trip was very well tailored for me, I have a lots of request (I can't stand 4WD's too long for), but he helped me out. He was telling a lots of true story about Hungarian history and these short tales always were related with the place where we were visiting. Zoltan Nagy is a highly educated guy, we had a very well presented trip with him, he's home in history, geography, archeology, architects ... and of course, in languages! His attitude and abilities are extraordinary, he wasn't only a simple tourist conductor, I felt myself as a highly respected guest. He prepared for us a special Hungarian dinner with famous wines,... yummy! I already recommended "rockhoppers" for my kiwi friends, they'll visiting Hungary at very first time in March. Good an you, mate, good as gold, rockhoppers and special thanks for Zoltan!  Keep doing that way! With love and nice memories, Marta Kubala xoxoxox

Zoltan is engaging and illuminating. My tour in Budapest was outstanding. I was absolutely freezing but Zotan was entertaining enough that it was still very informative and fun. He brings history to life with his amazing insight, knowledge, and wonderful story telling abilities. He knows how to reach his audience and put it all in context. His tour will no doubt deepen your appreciation for Budapest, Hungry and add immeasurably to your trip.

Budapest spirit is high. Hi, guys ;)I know, the best way to enjoy the place is to find friendly locals, who could show you around. I was lucky that I met Zoltan during my journey to BudaPest – he is brilliant guide and he knows every corner, every hidden part of the city. It was a great time, I really enjoyed discovering places, plunging into the bars and vineyards, listening to the legends and real stories. Zoltan is a great story-teller!So I would really strongly recommend you to get this fantastic experience – you know, ordinary touristic tracks are boring and doesn’t give you the feeling of the place. I had been in BP before, but only with Zoltan I got a real taste of this amazing city!

My best visit of Budapest and its Jewish history. When you go on a Jewish Tour in Budapest, you have some expectations and may even worry that the tour would not comply with your expectations. This was not the case now!The tour by Rockhoppers revealed the whole Jewish history in the territory of present Hungary from the Roman times. Beside the verbal info, we enjoyed a visual one, too, when walking across the Jewish Quarter of the city, and entered some old houses and talked with local people that lived there - and also tried some traditional Jewish cake, like "Flodni". I recommend it to everybody!

real Hungary. I really enjoyed Zoltan's guiding in Budapest and beyond. It was especially the Gypsy village that made us feel less like tourists or foreigners and more like guests. It is really worthwhile the get away from the main touristic attractions and try to grasp what Hungary and Hungarians are really all about. And Zoltan is the perfect guide to do it with. Not to mention the good wine, good conversation and authentic Gypsy music that's always part of the deal!Rockhoppers rulz!

perfect tour, lovely sightseeing. We, a group of students visited Budapest recently, and decided to take a tour with the Rockhoppers.We were eight people and fit in a Land Rover that took us through a forest to a small village, near Budapest, where the Gypsy people live.And the rest was a miracle!The first thing was a welcome drink by the owner of the pub where we spent the evening with delicious Gypsy goulash and some very gentle and soft wine! Meanwhile, the musicians played some music that we never heard before. It was the real, the authentic Gypsy music!Some of us were shy to dance, but the local people helped us to get rid of the complexes.Watch the video on the site and can have some idea about it, but the reality is much more than that!GREAT!

If start a year, than with Zoltan. We visited Budapest at the beginning of January. It was a 1 week long family trip - my husband, an 11 months old baby and myself got on the train in Warsaw and get off at Nuygati train station in the center of Budapest. We had Zoltan's contact from a friend who is a local. For 5 days, Zoltan was irreplacable. Not only had he shown us the city from amazing angles not possible to be found in tourist guides, but he also had shown extreme flexibility and sensitivity to our needs. Thanks to him, moving around the city with a baby was adventerous and not tiring at all. We were particularly impressed by his knowledge of cultural history of the city and a sense of humor and warm-heartedness. We hope he will remain a friend and that we will have a chance to hang out together in Budapest when the baby start walking steadily. We highly recommend!

THE MULTICULTURAL BUDAPEST. my tour to Budapest started really cold, it was hard winter and everywhere around was snow, as a Turkish from İstanbul it was impossible to be outside for me but Zoltan could make me walk around the city from morning till the evening cause his trip was really wonderful !! I had chance to see historical places with their real history stories. Zoltan is my colleague, we are both historians and from this trip till today we have been good friends also. I recommend you to see Budapest with him :)

Budapest is always new!. Budapest.The city of several cultures. Among them one of the Jewish centres of Europe.If somebody wants to get familiar with the Jewish culture of Central Eastern Europe, you can get the proper information on the tours of the Rockhoppers!Do it and enjoy it!I am sure, you will love it as much as I did it!Tomina, Oradea, Romania

Budapest is awesome!. Zoltan Nagy was a fabulous guide and host to my son and his friend when they spent a few days in Budapest following college graduation. They throughly enjoyed his company and had an awesome time seeing the local sites with him. Their time with him was definitely a highlight to their whirlwind trip!
perfect. i know Zoltan for a long time now, and he helped me to discover Budapest much better than i could do it by myself! thank you very much, im gonna come back!

The reason to return to Budapest. Only a tour guide like ours could make a cold walk through Budapest feel warm. Our tourguide, Zoltan, had a wealth of knowledge about everything you could ever possibly want to know about Budapest...and with a sense of humor. Thank you, Zoltan!

Best trip ever!. When coming from the center of the Ottoman world, Istanbul, it will be a place of great interest when you face the Turkish monuments of your own culture in a remote country. Budapest once was the edge of the Turkish Empire, and although the guidebooks do not report on many monuments from that period, the guide of Rockhoppers presented a whole bunch of Turkish buildings and told us about their history. Although the Turkish elements are only some old mihrabs or other parts of Catholic churches sometimes, the baths show their original splendour. The Turkish baths in Istanbul work with steam only, but here the miraculous hot springs make even the baths better than in Turkey.

Great experience of Hungary with an excellent guide.. We decided to take a chance with the Jewish Tour by Rockhoppers in Budapest.This was an outstanding experience that goes beyond far beyond normal tour experiences. We were taken inside of the amazing Jewish life of Budapest before the Shoa, the Holocaust. The guide that took us around brought us in the depth of the extremely special life of the Jews in Budapest. The Orthodox community, the Reformed Community and also the Hassidic, which was almost an antagonism in this city. The high-tech shops, the shopping malls, and in the same time the view of the Orthodox rabbis on the streets, followed by Gypsy ladies surrounded with several noisy children around her long and rose decorated skirts.A truly unique experience.

A trip to remember .... There are great tours in Hungary organised by Rockhoppers!We did the Gypsy tour, and it was a real day in our life!We drove across the region of Budapest inhabited mainly by the Gypsy. For us, people from Belgium, it was an exciting site!Leaving the region we drove across the forest into a small village, where we were received with some locally made brandy and tasty wine, and they also offered us delicious goulash, too.Meanwhile, the live music was on played by a group of young musicians. The Roma people were dancing madly.Suddenly, some of the local people took us into the dance, too! There was no stop but music and dance – supplemented sometimes with a sip of the wine!Unbelievable experience!Try it!

It was the Roman Tour by Rockhoppers that we tried.. The region of the north-western part of Budapest was once the capital of the Roman province called Pannonia. There are still several ruins and monuments in town that are very precious when you are interested in this ancient culture. The amphitheaters, the huge Roman bath, and the ruin of the civil town! Beautiful!I have to mention the second part of the tour, which was a visit in a village that was built in the old village Vinidium. However, the VINUM was real this time. We visited a wine-cellar of an old man that offered us fantastic wines! In order to make the wine tasting better we were offered some home-made sausages with paprika and home baked bread!And the guide Zoltan drove us back to the hotel safely. Louise and Christopher

The real gypsy thing. The Rockhoppers organized us a real review upon the Gypsy district of Budapest. Although the flyer said that we shall only drive across the district by car, we stopped and had some talk with the Roma on the streets and in a pub.And then came the strange thing. We drove into the forest with a Land Rover. After a drive on the NO ROADS we arrived in a small village among the hill and stopped by a pub where there were only Roma people. They just had a family celebration with live music, and we were offered goulash and drinks.The end was dance, dance, dance – THE GYPSY WAY!

ART NOVEAU WE LOVE YOU!. Myself a a group of friends recently visited Budapest as a group of students writing an essay about the city. When we first turned up for the tour we were not sure what to expect. However Zoltan, the guide was very friendly, helpful and informative and was happy to answer any further questions as we were quite keen. The only problem was the cold weather!

Great!. The tour in the Jewish Quarter and the Turkish monuments by Rockhoppers were amazing! We were introduced into the life of the present Jewish community and learnt a lot about the one before the Holocaust.I recommend it for everyone!Zoltan from the Rockhoppers reanimated the 16th century Ottoman Turkish Empire in front of our eyes.Thank you!

Gypsy Tour. The Gypsy Tour was fantastic!In the city of Budapest we saw the life of the „troublesome” districtfrom the car; however, later we took a ride across the forest (!) on NOROADS! Across the wild!And then we arrived in the pub of the Roma, where there was the greatmusic played!The owner of the pub received with a glass of “palinka” (=schnaps), whchwas followed by a great goulash and wine (or for the ones that preferredthat: beer!).It was just in vain to sitting about and listening to the music andwatching the dancers, we failed. They took us to the dance, and wedanced real Gypsy dances!Obviously, the glass of wine that was included in the price was notenough, so we ordered for some more at our own cost, but it was so goodthat we had a lot!The wine itself was worth to visit!The guide, Zoltan handled the Land Rover perfectly in the forest, andalthough our English was not too good, we could communicate either inRussian or in the mixture of Enaglish and German.It was one of the greatest events of our life!We shall be back, Zoltan!Thank you!RudiDresden, Deutchland

The tour with the Rockhoppers was fantastic!. After taking a ride in the 8th district of Budapest, which is kind of a Roma ghetto, the guide, Zoltan took us in a village across a deep forest, and we found ourselves in a Gypsy pub. They played live music there, and I did not know that this kind of authentic Gypsy music still exists! I cannot say that we remained all sober, but when you are given GOOD wine, it is just great!Thank you, we’ll be back!
Of knowledge dissemination tour in Budapest. Super interesting, fun, a serious education, reliable service, probably the best which they have participated so far. Recommended for everyone ...

Rockhoppers a good way to experience Budapest. While on a long weekend trip to Hungary in September 2010, we had the good fortune to be introduced to Budapest's Jewish Quarter through the eyes of Rockhoppers.hu guide Zoltan Nagy. In addition to his encyclopedic knowledge of the history of the area, Zoltan has obviously invested the time needed to develop close, personal relationships with the residents and staff at even the smallest sites. As he narrated our way through the maze of streets, locked gates leading to inner courtyards and doors historic buildings opened as if by magic and we were welcomed in. This tour was the clear highlight of our visit, and we are looking forward to the opportunity to return to Budapest to explore more aspects of the city with the help of this remarkable guide.
